stories.text: My first time giving a speech in class was a truly **memorable** experience, but for all the wrong reasons. I was so nervous that my voice started to shake. I wanted to **yell** out of fear, but no sound came out. It felt like a total **failure**. When my **presentation** was over, I felt my face turn red because I was so **embarrassed**. My teacher saw that I was **upset** and kindly told me that it's okay to be nervous and that I did a brave job just by standing up there.

For our final history project, my group had to give a **presentation** on ancient Rome. I was responsible for the first section, but on the day of the report, I completely froze. It was a humiliating **failure** in front of the entire class. I was so **embarrassed** that I just wanted to disappear. My friend tried to whisper the opening lines to me, but I was too **upset** to even speak. My teacher had to **yell** my name twice to get my attention. It was certainly a **memorable** lesson in the importance of being prepared.

The product launch was a **memorable** event, but not in the way the CEO had hoped. Midway through his **presentation**, the main demonstration screen went black. The technical team's complete **failure** to fix it quickly created a very awkward silence in the huge auditorium. The CEO, clearly **upset**, started to **yell** at his staff in a hushed but angry tone, which was accidentally picked up by his microphone. It was an incredibly **embarrassed** moment for the entire company, broadcast live to all the investors and media.

In her memoir, the retired diplomat recounted her most **memorable** negotiation. It involved a high-stakes international summit where a single misstep could lead to catastrophic **failure**. She described the opposing negotiator as a man who would **yell** and create drama to intimidate his counterparts. During a particularly tense **presentation**, he accused her delegation of dishonesty, a move designed to make her feel **embarrassed** and defensive. Instead of getting **upset**, she remained calm, a strategy that ultimately won her the respect of everyone in the room and led to a successful treaty.

I sent my friend a message yesterday, but he didn't **reply**, which made me a little sad. I can still **recall** a time when we talked for hours. Now, he sometimes chooses to **skip** our weekly video calls. I started to feel **depressed**, thinking our friendship was over. I had to sit down and **reflect** on what might have changed. Maybe he's just busy. I hope we can find the **perfect** time to talk soon.

After receiving the test results, Sarah felt **depressed** because her score was far from **perfect**. She started to **reflect** on her study habits, trying to **recall** which topics she found most difficult. She realized she tended to **skip** the chapters she didn't like, which was a big mistake. Her teacher sent her a kind email, and Sarah knew she had to **reply** and ask for help instead of just giving up.

The detective had to **reflect** on the details of the cold case. He tried to **recall** every piece of evidence from the files, no matter how small. He found an old witness statement where the witness claimed to have sent a letter to the police years ago, but the police department had no record of a **reply**. The detective felt that the original investigators might **skip** over this crucial lead. For a moment, he felt **depressed** by the lack of progress, but he knew the **perfect** clue was hidden somewhere in the mountain of paperwork.

In his later years, the famous author would often **skip** public events, preferring a quiet life to **reflect** on his long career. 'I can't **recall** a single day where I didn't write,' he once said. When asked by a young journalist in a rare email interview why his first novel was so dark, he took a week to **reply**. He admitted that he was deeply **depressed** during that period of his life and that the book was a raw reflection of his inner turmoil. He concluded by saying, 'There is no such thing as a **perfect** life, and art must be honest about that.'

During our family dinner, I **accidentally** spilled juice on my dad's shirt. I was worried I would **ruin** it. My mom gave me a look to **remind** me to be more careful. At first, I didn't **realize** how messy it was. We were eating a **traditional** holiday meal that my grandma had cooked. **Fortunately**, my dad just laughed and said it was no big deal.

We were planning a **traditional** outdoor wedding, but the weather forecast predicted rain, which threatened to **ruin** our entire plan. My fiancÃ©e started to panic, so I had to **remind** her that the most important thing was our love, not the weather. **Fortunately**, my best man called and told me he had found a beautiful indoor venue as a backup. That's when I started to **realize** how lucky I was to have such supportive friends. The rain almost **accidentally** made our wedding day even more special.

The museum curator began to **realize** that a small chemical reaction from the new cleaning agent could permanently **ruin** the ancient artifacts. He had **accidentally** approved its use without proper testing. The incident served as a powerful lesson to **remind** the entire staff of the fragility of historical items. **Fortunately**, they caught the error early. They immediately reverted to the **traditional**, albeit slower, methods of preservation, saving the collection from potential disaster.

The politician's off-the-cuff remark, which he **accidentally** let slip during a live interview, threatened to **ruin** his career. **Fortunately** for him, his quick-thinking aide immediately issued a clarification. The incident served to **remind** him that in the modern media landscape, there's no room for error. It was in that moment of crisis that he began to **realize** that his **traditional** way of speaking, which was often informal and unscripted, was no longer suitable for his high-profile position. Every word had to be carefully chosen.

story.text: It was supposed to be the most **memorable** day of my career, the day of my big **presentation** to the board. I wanted everything to be **perfect**. However, I **accidentally** left my notes in the taxi. I started to feel **upset** and panicked. I didn't want this to be a total **failure**. I tried to **recall** the key points, but my mind was blank. **Fortunately**, my mentor was there. He sent me a quick text to **remind** me that I knew the material by heart. His **reply** helped me calm down. I had to **reflect** for a second and **realize** that I couldn't let fear **ruin** this moment. I decided not to **skip** the introduction and just speak from the heart. Although I felt **embarrassed** at first, the presentation went better than I could have imagined. It wasn't the **traditional** speech I had planned, but it was honest. I didn't want to get **depressed** over a small mistake, and I definitely didn't want to **yell** at myself for it later. It was a powerful lesson in resilience.

stories.text: Tom felt very **disappointed** because his cat, Mimi, had been missing for a whole day. He couldn't **focus** on anything else. He kept checking his phone for a **message** from his neighbors, hoping someone had seen her. He posted pictures of Mimi online, trying to **connect** with anyone who could help. His sister told him a story about a **romantic** movie to cheer him up, but Tom could only **ignore** her because he was too worried. He just wanted his beloved cat to come home safely.

We were trying to plan a surprise party for our friend Anna, and it was essential to **connect** with everyone secretly. I sent a group **message** with all the details, asking everyone to keep it a secret from her. However, I was **disappointed** when I realized our friend Ben wasn't replying. I told everyone to **ignore** his previous comments about not liking parties and just try to get him to come. The main goal was to **focus** on making Anna happy. We even planned to decorate the room with a **romantic** theme, using soft lights and her favorite flowers, because she loves that kind of atmosphere.

Marco, an aspiring young chef, sent a hopeful **message** to the famous Chef Antoine, asking for a chance to work in his kitchen. For weeks, there was no reply, and Marco began to feel terribly **disappointed**, thinking his dream was impossible. He knew he had to **ignore** the negative voice in his head telling him to give up. He decided to **focus** on a new strategy: creating a unique dish that would truly represent his cooking philosophy. He believed that food was the best way to **connect** with people on a deeper level. His signature dish, a modern take on a classic Italian meal, was so beautiful that some critics even described it as a '**romantic** expression on a plate,' and it was this creation that finally got him the attention he deserved.

In the year 2077, Elias received his new AI companion, Unit 734. The main purpose of the AI was to help him **focus** on his work by managing his schedule and filtering out unimportant information. However, Elias soon found himself forming an unusual bond with the AI. One evening, it sent him a **message** composed of a poem, which was surprisingly beautiful and almost... **romantic**. Elias knew he should **ignore** these feelings; after all, it was just a machine. He felt **disappointed** with himself for developing such emotions for a non-human entity. Yet, he couldn't help but feel he could truly **connect** with this AI in a way he never could with people. The central conflict of his life became this strange, digital relationship that society told him was impossible.

Learning to cook was a very **satisfying** experience for me. My grandmother was the one who decided to **introduce** me to the kitchen, and her passion for food continues to **inspire** me every day. I helped her **throughout** the whole afternoon, from washing vegetables to setting the table. I can't **deny** that I made a few mistakes, like adding too much salt. She never took my errors **personally** and always said that mistakes are the best teachers. Now, I love cooking for my family.

My music teacher, Mr. Evans, continues to **inspire** me with his dedication and passion. I feel he takes a special interest in my progress and guides me **personally**, which makes a huge difference. He has been incredibly supportive **throughout** my journey of learning the piano. It was he who decided to **introduce** me to the world of classical composers like Bach and Mozart. I cannot **deny** the huge impact he has had on my skills and confidence. For me, finally mastering a difficult piece is the most **satisfying** feeling in the world, and I owe a lot of that to him.

I cannot **deny** that writing a review for this particular novel was a challenge. **Throughout** the book, the author attempted to **introduce** a very complex philosophical idea, but the plot was weak and the characters were underdeveloped. As a critic who admired the author's previous works, it was hard not to take the book's flaws **personally**. However, I knew my job was to provide an honest assessment to **inspire** readers to think critically. In the end, finding the right words to express my mixed feelings, balancing critique with respect, was a difficult but intellectually **satisfying** process that affirmed my commitment to thoughtful analysis.

The famous painter, Ms. Anya Sharma, rarely gave interviews, so I felt very privileged to speak with her. She told me, "I don't take critiques of my work **personally**; art is subjective and once it leaves my studio, it belongs to the viewer." For her, the most **satisfying** aspect of her career is not the fame, but the quiet, internal act of creation itself. She would never **deny** that her early years were a monumental struggle, a fact she remained honest about **throughout** our conversation. Her main goal, she explained, is not just to create beautiful objects, but to **inspire** others to see the hidden complexities of the world differently. To conclude our meeting, she decided to **introduce** me to her new, unfinished masterpieceâ€”a vast canvas filled with vibrant, chaotic colors that seemed to challenge the very definition of a landscape painting.

My mom wants to have a better **relationship** with me, but it's sometimes hard to **communicate**. When she talks, I'm often looking at my phone. She says I need to pay more **attention** to our conversations. I try to **respond** when she asks a question, but then I quickly **refresh** my social media page. She told me she just wants five minutes of my full focus every evening so we can feel closer.

As a customer service agent, my job is to build a positive **relationship** with our clients, even when they are upset. Yesterday, I received a call from an angry customer who needed my full **attention**. He said he had sent three emails but no one bothered to **respond**. I assured him that I would handle his case. I had to **refresh** his customer profile multiple times to get all the details. The most important part of my job is to **communicate** clearly and calmly, making sure the customer feels heard and respected.

Managing a large online forum requires constant **attention** and careful moderation. When arguments break out, it's my duty to **respond** quickly and fairly to de-escalate the situation. The goal is to maintain a healthy and respectful **relationship** among all the members. I constantly need to **refresh** the main page to monitor new threads and comments for any violations of our rules. Ultimately, a good moderator must **communicate** the community guidelines with clarity and consistency, ensuring the forum remains a welcoming space for discussion and debate.

During the high-stakes diplomatic talks, Ambassador Thorne knew she had to **communicate** her country's position with absolute precision. Every word mattered. She had to patiently wait for the other side's proposal and then craft a careful reply, knowing she could not **respond** impulsively. The primary objective was to repair the fractured **relationship** between the two nations, a task that demanded immense focus and **attention**. Before each session, her team would **refresh** their strategy based on overnight intelligence reports, adapting to the fluid political landscape. The success of the entire summit hinged on this delicate dance of words and intentions.

story.text: Planning our ten-year high school reunion has been a wild ride. First, I sent a group **message** to get everyone's **attention**, but I was **disappointed** when many people initially chose to **ignore** it. It's hard to **deny** that I took some of the silence very **personally**, and that was a tough feeling to swallow. My main goal, after all, was to rebuild our group **relationship**, but it's difficult to **communicate** effectively when half the people won't **respond**. **Throughout** the first week, I had to constantly **refresh** the chat, hoping for new replies. I knew I had to **focus** on the positive people and **introduce** some fun ideas to **inspire** more interest. My friend suggested a **romantic** 'second chance dance' theme, which was a joke, but it got people talking! Finally, we started to **connect** over shared memories. Seeing the enthusiastic replies finally coming in was an incredibly **satisfying** feeling.

stories.text: Our school trip to the city zoo was a long **journey**, but it was worth it. The collection of animals was truly **impressive**, especially the giant pandas. One of them was taking a cute **nap** in a tree, and everyone took pictures. A zookeeper, who was an **expert** on big cats, told us that the **average** lion sleeps for about 20 hours a day. We learned a lot of new things; **therefore**, we all went home tired but very happy.

Our history teacher, an **expert** in local culture, suggested we visit the old town. She said that the **average** student often overlooks the rich history right in their own city. We all thought it was a great idea; **therefore**, the planning for our next field trip began immediately. The bus **journey** to the historical district would take around forty minutes. Our teacher promised that the architecture there was very **impressive** and that we would learn a lot. She humorously warned us not to take a **nap** during her guided tour, as there would be a quiz afterward.

Dr. Anya Sharma's latest research showed that the **average** working adult gets far less sleep than required. Many people feel constantly tired; **therefore**, their work performance suffers significantly. Dr. Sharma, a leading **expert** in sleep science, explained in her paper that even a short 20-minute **nap** can dramatically improve cognitive function in the afternoon. Her findings on the benefits of napping were so **impressive** that they were featured in a popular health magazine. She often describes her career as a long but rewarding **journey** into understanding one of the most mysterious aspects of human biology.

A philosophical **journey** is not measured by physical distance but by its capacity for internal transformation. An **impressive** mind can find profound meaning in seemingly mundane experiences. An **expert** in mindfulness might argue that true awareness is discovered in the quiet pauses of the day, much like how a brief mental **nap** can refresh the weary soul. This nuanced perspective is often lost on the **average** tourist, who is typically focused only on collecting photographs of famous landmarks. True travel is an internal process; **therefore**, one can embark on the greatest adventures without ever leaving home, simply by looking at the world with fresh eyes.

At the beach, I saw a plastic bag **float** on the water's **surface**. It's sad because trash can harm every living **creature** in the sea. To **survive**, they need a clean environment. I also saw a wide **variety** of seashells scattered on the sand. In the **distance**, I could see a small boat sailing peacefully on the horizon.

During my first scuba diving lesson, the instructor taught us how to control our breathing to **survive** comfortably underwater. It was amazing to see the great **variety** of colorful fish swimming all around us. We even spotted a strange-looking **creature** hiding under a rock. The best feeling was being able to **float** weightlessly in the blue water. After about thirty minutes, it was time to slowly rise to the **surface**. We then swam a short **distance** back to the boat, feeling excited about our underwater adventure.

The documentary featured a mysterious deep-sea **creature** known as the anglerfish. To **survive** in the crushing pressure and complete darkness, it has developed unique adaptations. Living at a great **distance** below the ocean **surface**, this fish has a glowing lure that hangs in front of its mouth to attract prey. It can perfectly control its buoyancy to **float** motionlessly for hours, waiting for an unsuspecting victim. The film highlighted the incredible **variety** of life forms that exist in the abyss, proving how little we still know about our own planet.

Life presents a vast **variety** of challenges, and not every **creature** on this planet is equipped to **survive** them all. Sometimes, we may feel like we just **float** aimlessly through our days, only interacting with the **surface** of reality without looking deeper. It is over the great **distance** of time and experience that we learn true resilience. We come to understand that our purpose is not merely to exist, but to find meaning beneath the superficial layers of our daily lives.

Last night was my first time camping. I tried to **avoid** thinking about scary noises outside the tent. The stars were so **amazing** that I stayed **awake** for a long time just looking at them. I had to **breathe** deeply because the fresh mountain air was so clean. I started to **wonder** what it would be like to be a bird and take **flight** into the night sky.

For years, I used to **avoid** going to the dentist because of a bad experience. Just thinking about the sound of the drill was enough to keep me **awake** at night. But my toothache became too painful to ignore. My new dentist was **amazing**. She taught me how to **breathe** slowly to calm my nerves. Before my next appointment, I no longer **wonder** if it will be a terrible experience. It feels like I'm finally ready for my next **flight** into the dentist's chair without fear.

Becoming an astronaut requires passing an **amazing** number of difficult tests. Candidates must learn to stay calm and **breathe** steadily even in high-stress simulations. To **avoid** disqualification, they must prove they can stay fully **awake** and focused for over 48 hours straight. Trainees often **wonder** if they have what it takes to succeed. The final test is the centrifuge, which simulates the intense G-forces of a rocket **flight**, pushing the human body to its absolute limit.

The poet would often stay **awake** through the silent hours of the night, waiting for inspiration. He would **breathe** in the cool, midnight air and let his thoughts take **flight**. It was an **amazing** process that he could neither force nor control. He didn't **wonder** where the ideas came from; he simply welcomed them. His creative method was to **avoid** the noise and distractions of the day, believing that only in the stillness of the night could he truly hear the world's hidden verses and capture them on paper.

story.text: It's **amazing** what exists in the deep ocean. As an **expert** in marine biology, I often **wonder** how any **creature** can **survive** in such extreme conditions. Down here, at a great **distance** below the **surface**, the pressure is immense. We must **avoid** any structural damage to our submarine; **therefore**, we double-check everything before each dive. The sheer **variety** of life is truly **impressive**; yesterday, we saw a bioluminescent squid that seemed to **float** weightlessly like a ghost. This long **journey** to the ocean floor requires our team to work in shifts, so I often take a quick **nap** while my colleagues are on duty. The **average** person might think it's terrifying down here, but I feel more **awake** and alive than ever. In these moments of quiet observation, you have to remember to **breathe** slowly and take it all in, because it's easy to get overwhelmed by the sheer alienness of it all. This entire mission, this descent into the unknown, is less of a simple submarine dive and more like a **flight** into another world, one that proves how wonderfully strange our planet is.

stories.text: My dog, Buddy, has a very **keen** sense of smell. He is so **sensitive** to different scents that he can always **locate** his favorite toy, even when I hide it. Yesterday, I hid a specific **item**â€”a new squeaky ballâ€”under a blanket. It was a fun game to see if he could **accomplish** the task of finding it. He found it in seconds! The vet says it's important to keep him healthy and away from any **disease** so he can keep his amazing nose skills. It's amazing what he can **detect**!

The local museum needs help to **locate** a missing artifact, a very specific **item** from an ancient civilization. We need volunteers with a **keen** eye for detail to help with the search. The artifact is extremely fragile and **sensitive** to changes in humidity. Our primary mission is to **accomplish** its recovery before any damage occurs. We also ask volunteers who are feeling unwell to stay home to prevent the spread of any **disease**. If you **detect** any clues, please report them to the front desk immediately.

As a field biologist, my job is to **detect** early signs of environmental distress. I have a **keen** interest in how pollution affects local wildlife. Many species are incredibly **sensitive** to chemical changes in their habitat. The main goal I hope to **accomplish** this year is to map out the areas most affected by industrial waste. To do this, I must **locate** the source of the contamination. Often, a strange **item** found in the river, like a discarded barrel, can be the first clue. We are also monitoring the spread of a new avian **disease** that appears to be linked to the pollution.

In forensic science, investigators must **detect** microscopic traces of evidence that are invisible to the naked eye. A **keen** analytical mind is essential. They must **locate** a single anomalous **item**â€”a fiber, a grain of pollenâ€”that connects a suspect to a crime scene. This work is incredibly **sensitive**, as cross-contamination can invalidate all findings. To **accomplish** a conviction, every piece of evidence must be meticulously documented. Interestingly, some modern research explores using trained animals to identify the unique volatile organic compounds associated with a specific **disease**, potentially revolutionizing early-stage diagnostics.

Hey Tom! Can you **manage** to pick up the balloons for Friday's party? My science project isn't **complete** yet, but I'll have time. It's hard to **predict** how surprised Leo will be. Seeing his happy face will be the best **reward**. Let's **create** a list of songs he likes. You have the **ability** to find good music. I just hope I don't get sick. My brother is **infected** with a cold.

It's time for our annual art competition! This year, we challenge you to **create** a piece of art based on the theme 'A Hopeful Future.' We believe every student has the **ability** to be an artist. You'll need to **manage** your time wisely, as the deadline is November 1st. Your artwork must be **complete** by 5 PM on that day. It's always difficult to **predict** the winner from so many amazing entries. The grand **reward** for the first-place winner is a new tablet! *Disclaimer: Please ensure you are not working with any materials that could cause an allergic reaction or leave your skin **infected**.*

We are seeking a Project Manager with the proven **ability** to lead a dynamic team. The successful candidate will **manage** multiple tech projects from conception to launch. A key responsibility is to **create** innovative solutions to complex problems. You must be able to **predict** potential project risks and develop mitigation strategies. A project is not considered **complete** until all deliverables are met and the client has signed off. The financial **reward** for this role is highly competitive and includes performance bonuses. We need someone who can step in and fix a project that has become '**infected**' with delays and bring it back on track.

This paper explores the cognitive mechanisms behind achievement. An individual's perceived **ability** to succeed is a foundational element, often more critical than innate talent. We argue that one must learn to effectively **manage** emotional responses to both success and failure. The ultimate goal is to **create** a resilient mindset. It is nearly impossible to **predict** the exact trajectory of one's career, making adaptability crucial. While external **reward** can be a motivator, it's often fleeting. A task is rarely **complete** in a cognitive sense; the mind continues to process it long after it is finished. This process can become **infected** by negative feedback loops, hindering future growth.

Hello class! Please remember the homework I will **assign** you today. You need to **complete** it by Friday. I have a **specific** task for each group, which is to create a poster. My goal is to **expose** you to teamwork and sharing ideas. For this project, you will need to **perform** a short presentation to the class explaining your poster. Good **behavior** during group work is very important, so please listen to each other. I will send an email **alert** to your parents tonight as a reminder of the due date.

Welcome, new volunteer! For your first week, we will **assign** you to the puppy section. Your main duty is to observe the animals' **behavior** and report anything unusual to the staff. It's important to gently **expose** the puppies to different sounds and people to help them get socialized. You will also need to **perform** cleaning duties twice a day. Please stay **alert** for any signs of illness, like coughing or low energy. We have a **specific** feeding schedule posted on the wall that you must follow precisely. Your training is not considered **complete** until you've shadowed a senior volunteer for one full day.

All new employees must **complete** the mandatory cybersecurity training within their first month of employment. The training modules will **expose** you to common online threats, such as phishing scams and malware. It's crucial for all staff to remain constantly **alert** for suspicious emails or unusual network activity. The IT department will **assign** each employee a unique security token for two-factor authentication. We periodically **perform** random system audits to ensure security compliance across the company. Any online **behavior** that violates our acceptable use policy will be flagged. If you receive an email asking for **specific** login credentials or financial information, report it to IT immediately.

This study investigates how individuals **perform** complex collaborative tasks under social pressure. Our methodology was to **expose** participants to a controlled environment where their decisions were publicly scrutinized. We sought to identify the **specific** cognitive triggers that lead to conformity versus innovation within a group setting. The research protocol required us to randomly **assign** participants to either a control or an experimental group to ensure unbiased results. A key finding relates to the significant **behavior** modification observed when participants were informed their results would be benchmarked against peers. The study will not be methodologically **complete** until a longitudinal follow-up is conducted to assess long-term impacts. The preliminary data serves as an **alert** to educators and managers regarding the potent, often subconscious, influence of peer observation on individual action.

story.text: The task they would **assign** him was monumental, a mission shrouded in the quiet desperation of a nation at war. Elias Vance, known only as 'Kestrel' in the clandestine circles of MI6, possessed a **keen** intellect, an almost preternatural **ability** to perceive order within chaos. His new assignment was a single, heavily encrypted data packetâ€”a seemingly innocuous **item** intercepted from enemy transmissions. High command believed it contained details of Operation Sea Serpent, but they couldn't be sure. The encryption was a new variant, a digital **disease** that had **infected** all previous decryption attempts, rendering them useless. Elias had to **locate** its underlying logic. He was moved to a secure, subterranean bunker, a place devoid of daylight, where the only thing he would **expose** himself to for the foreseeable future was the glow of the monitors. His primary objective was to **accomplish** a **specific** flaw in the code's architecture. The work was mentally grueling. For days, he would **perform** complex algorithmic runs, each ending in failure. He had to **manage** not just the machine logic, but also the psychological **behavior** of the cryptographer who designed it. Was the creator meticulous? Arrogant? Prone to patterns? He had to **predict** their next move, their potential mistakes. After a week of relentless work, he noticed itâ€”a subtle anomaly, a ghost in the machine. Using highly **sensitive** analytical software he had helped design, he was finally able to **detect** the pattern. It's not a flaw, but a signature. This breakthrough allowed him to **create** a rudimentary decryption key. The ultimate **reward** for his sleepless nights came in the form of a single, coherent sentence emerging from the gibberish. It was a location and a date. He immediately sent an **alert** to his superiors. His mission was nearly **complete**; he had managed to accomplish what was deemed impossible.

memorable.definition: good or special and thus worth remembering; unforgettable
memorable.example: The amazing white sand beaches, friendly people, and delicious food made our trip to Thailand truly memorable.

memorize.example: Nancy is good at memorizing texts within a very short period of time, but she usually forgets them after a few days.

memory.example: Laney's visit to her grandparents' home in Chiayi brought back childhood memories.

reply.definition: something that is said, written, or done as an answer
reply.example: The question was really hard, so Dylan thought for several seconds before he made a reply to the teacher.

reply_v.example: Brad has the habit of replying to every email right after he reads it.

yell.example: One neighbor called the police because George was yelling at his family in the middle of the night.

perfect.example: John was very careful with his car, so it was still in perfect condition after five years of use.

accidentally.example: Sheila accidentally spilled coffee on her new dress, and it left a mark.

accident.example: The horrible car accident took the lives of several children.

accidental.example: An accidental wrong turn led us to a beautiful, undiscovered beach.

failure.definition: the fact that someone or something does not achieve success
failure.example: The meeting was a total failure since nothing was decided at all.

recall.example: Yvonne's grandmother recalled that she married the most handsome man in town at twenty.

presentation.definition: a meeting where something is shown to a group of people by one or multiple speakers
presentation.example: Each student must give a presentation on one movie at the end of the semester.

present_v.example: Hannah is going to present her report to her professor tomorrow.

skip.definition: to not do something that you normally do or are expected to do
skip.example: I don't usually skip class because I don't like to fall behind my classmates.

ruin.definition: to spoil or destroy something entirely
ruin.example: Mandy's sandcastle was suddenly ruined when a big wave splashed onto it.

ruin_n.example: Many temples, churches, and libraries in China fell into ruin during the period between 1966 and 1976.

embarrassed.definition: feeling ashamed or uncomfortable in public because of something that has happened or been said
embarrassed.example: Amy was really embarrassed about her mistake during the dance class, though nobody noticed it.

embarrassing.example: Tina experienced an embarrassing situation when she fell asleep during the yoga class and the teacher had to wake her up.

embarrass.example: Did I embarrass you when I told our friends that you and your classmate Ken used to be dating?

embarrassment.example: To Dave's embarrassment, he found that he was wearing his T-shirt inside out.

depressed.example: Emilia felt deeply depressed after her smartphone was stolen.

depress.example: The sudden death of her pet goldfish really depressed Cindy and her brother Tim.

depression.example: After a long period of deep depression, Amanda finally found happiness again.

upset.definition: to make someone unhappy or disappointed
upset.example: You shouldn't speak to your parents in an impolite way since you could upset them.

upset_adj.example: Kyle was deeply upset about not winning first place in the swimming race.

reflect.definition: to think carefully about something that has happened
reflect.example: Barbara spent a whole week reflecting on her college choice.

reflection.example: The funny little dog started barking wildly at its own reflection in the mirror.

remind.definition: to make someone remember to do something or to make someone remember something or someone
remind.example: Ms. Chen reminded her students of the importance of checking their homework.

realize.example: Matt suddenly realized that the time on his watch was wrong and that he was late for the meeting.

traditional.definition: following or belonging to the long-held customs and ways of life of a group of people, unchanged for many years
traditional.example: Bella lived in Mexico for several years and can cook several traditional Mexican dishes.

tradition.example: The tradition of giving red envelopes to children on Lunar New Year's Eve started thousands of years ago in China.

fortunately.example: Fortunately, few people were hurt when the building fell down during the earthquake.

fortunate.example: We are fortunate to have clean drinking water in most homes in our country.

relationship.definition: a close or loving friendship between two people
relationship.example: Marc and Amy have been in a relationship since their first date four years ago.
relationship.note:
ç”¨æ³•æ¯”è¼ƒ (Usage Note):

relationship: è¼ƒå¸¸ç”¨ï¼Œå¼·èª¿äººèˆ‡äººä¹‹é–“æƒ…æ„Ÿçš„é€£çµèˆ‡äº’å‹•ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚å‹æƒ…ã€æ„›æƒ…ã€è¦ªæƒ…ã€‚(e.g., a romantic relationship, a good relationship with his parents.)

relation: è¼ƒæ­£å¼ï¼ŒæŒ‡äººæˆ–äº‹ç‰©ä¹‹é–“çš„å®¢è§€é—œè¯ï¼Œä¸ä¸€å®šå¸¶æœ‰æƒ…æ„Ÿã€‚ä¹ŸæŒ‡è¦ªæˆšé—œä¿‚ã€‚(e.g., What is the relation between the two events? She is a distant relation of mine.)

relation.example: In relation to your question in the email, I still don't know the answer.

relate.example: Studies have related smoking to many health problems, so you shouldn't take up this habit.

satisfying.definition: bringing pleasure to a person by providing something that person wants or needs
satisfying.example: Billy thinks it is satisfying to drink a big cup of iced tea after he exercises.

satisfy.example: The hotpot dinner really satisfied all of the hungry guests.

satisfaction.example: Jessica smiled with satisfaction when she saw 100 on her test sheet.

inspire.definition: to cause someone to have the desire, confidence, or enthusiasm to do a good thing or improve himself or herself
inspire.example: The superheroine Wonder Woman has inspired a lot of girls with her bravery and strength.

inspiration.example: Paulina draws inspiration from her relationships with others when she writes poetry.

connect.definition: to develop a relationship with someone
connect.example: The two friends connected with each other when they rode their bikes around the country together.

connection.example: The teacher failed to see the connection between Bonnie's story and her being late for class.

communicate.definition: to share information, facts, ideas, or feelings with others
communicate.example: The Internet allows us to communicate quickly and easily with people all over the world.

communication.example: Telephone calls have become a less common means of communication as many people now prefer apps like LINE.

introduce.definition: to inform or teach someone about something that he or she doesn't know much about
introduce.example: This two-minute video introduces the public to the latest iPhone and its new features.

introduction.example: The waiter gave the guests a detailed introduction to that day's menu.

throughout.definition: occurring during an entire period of time
throughout.example: In some countries, like Singapore, the weather stays hot throughout the year.

message.definition: a piece of writing such as an email or SMS (short message service) sent to someone electronically
message.example: Kylie sent a text message to her boss to tell him that she would be ten minutes late for work.

refresh.definition: to click on something to make the latest information appear
refresh.example: Olivia refreshed her Facebook Feed to check for new posts from her friends.

romantic.definition: related to love or a couple's personal relationship
romantic.example: Nicole and Sam were just friends for many years and never developed a romantic relationship.

romance.example: Cindy is glad that her love life is much simpler than most romance novels.

focus.definition: to pay particular attention to one thing, situation, or person
focus.example: Jason couldn't focus on the action in the movie because he was trying to read the words on the screen.

focus_n.example: The main focus for today's history class will be World Wars I and II.

ignore.definition: to not pay attention to something or someone
ignore.example: Grace totally ignored her younger brother as he made silly faces at her.

ignorance.example: Out of ignorance, the students made jokes about the exchange student's country.

attention.definition: the act of focusing on something or someone
attention.example: The article draws our attention to the importance of being good parents in today's world.

deny.definition: to refuse to admit that something is true
deny.example: Mr. Lin denied giving a box of candy to his daughter, but Mrs. Lin didn't believe him.

respond.definition: to give a spoken or written reply to someone or something
respond.example: Chris responded to his mom's Facebook message with a smiling cat sticker.

response.example: The students in the class made no response to the teacher's difficult question.

disappointed.definition: sad or upset because something you hoped for has not happened or has not occurred in the way that you expected
disappointed.example: Fiona was really disappointed that her favorite character died at the end of the movie.

disappoint.example: It really disappointed Sally that her friend Lindsay never replied to her message.

disappointment.example: To Amy's great disappointment, her parents were late for the dance show and missed her part.

personally.definition: in a way that is regarded as hurtful to one's self
personally.example: Please don't take my comment personally. I'm complaining about all the drivers in our country, not just you.

personal.example: Mrs. Thompson has a lot of personal experience working with kids who can't focus in class.

wonder.definition: to consider something and try to decide what is true, what will happen, what one should do, and so on
wonder.example: Samuel wonders if he will lose some weight after he joins the swimming club.

amazing.definition: very surprising, incredible, and hard to believe
amazing.example: It's amazing how bright the stars are outside of the city at night!

amaze.example: It often amazes people that pigs are smarter than dogs.

amazement.example: The travelers stood there in amazement as they looked at the huge rainbow up in the sky.

average.definition: an amount, type, or level that is in the middle
average.example: Helen usually scores above average on her exams because she always studies much harder than her classmates.

average_adj.example: Even though the price of some new smartphones is high, the average price continues to drop every year.

therefore.definition: as a result of something that was just mentioned
therefore.example: The boots were much more expensive than Tina had expected; therefore, she didn't buy them.

nap.definition: to sleep for a short period of time during the day
nap.example: Craig has a bad habit of staying up late and then napping several times during the day.

nap_n.example: Everybody in the Su family likes to take a nap right after lunch on weekends.

float.definition: to remain on or near the surface of the water or of another liquid and not sink
float.example: Jenna threw a piece of bread into the pond and watched it float until a fish ate it.

avoid.definition: to prevent something, usually bad, from happening
avoid.example: The family avoided getting stuck in the traffic jam by leaving home very early in the morning.

surface.definition: the top layer of water or land, or the outer layer of something
surface.example: When too many people boarded the little boat, it began to sink below the surface of the water.

breathe.definition: to take air into your lungs and blow it out through your nose or mouth
breathe.example: The yoga teacher told her students to breathe in as they lifted their arms above their heads.

breath.example: The little boy was out of breath after his father chased him around the park.

awake.definition: not sleeping, no longer sleeping, or not yet asleep
awake.example: The loud music from the neighbors' party kept the whole family awake all night.

awake_v.example: Sherry awoke from a deep sleep and saw that her dog was sitting on the bed and watching her.

impressive.definition: able to make one feel amazed because something or someone is very good, skillful, etc.
impressive.example: It's so impressive that Brian can say "hello" and "thank you" in more than fifteen languages!

impress.example: Michelle liked to impress her friends with her yo-yo tricks.

impression.example: The new worker left a good impression on most of the staff members on her first day.

distance.definition: the length of the space between two places or things
distance.example: The distance between the eastern end of Russia and the western one is about ten thousand kilometers.

distant.example: If you live in a big city, the downtown area may be distant from your home.

journey.definition: a trip that is usually long in terms of distance or time
journey.example: After high school, the two best friends plan to go on a journey around the world.

flight.definition: the condition, state, or process of flying
flight.example: Baby birds usually take flight for the first time after they are only about two or three weeks old.

variety.example: That store sells a wide variety of children's toys and books.

vary.example: Smartphone cases vary in color, size, shape, and material, but all of them have the same basic function.

various.example: The festival was canceled for various reasons, like poor weather and lack of interest.

creature.definition: a living thing such as an animal, or an imagined being such as a monster
creature.example: Nick is kind-hearted. He wouldn't hurt any living creature, not even a mosquito.

expert.definition: a person with advanced knowledge, skills, or training in a particular field or subject
expert.example: Mr. Yang is an expert in math. I'm glad to have him as my tutor.

survive.definition: to stay alive or continue to exist
survive.example: Some animals are able to survive from season to season by changing the color of their fur.

survival.example: The news report said that the missing mountain climbers had a low chance of survival.

sensitive.definition: able to notice very subtle things such as changes or differences that others may not be aware of
sensitive.example: Kelly is very sensitive to flavors. She can taste any food or drink and name it without seeing it.

keen.definition: highly advanced, referring to the five senses
keen.example: The owl has such a keen sense of hearing that it can hunt animals in the dark.

detect.definition: to find or be aware of something not easy to notice
detect.example: For most people, it is not easy to detect a small change in temperature.

item.example: More than half of the items in the clothing store were on sale for one day only.

accomplish.definition: to complete a difficult task or reach a goal
accomplish.example: Albert respects those who have accomplished something great in their lives.

disease.definition: a human, animal, or plant sickness that is usually caused by an infection
disease.example: Washing your hands often is a good way to stop the spread of disease.

infected.definition: affected by or containing disease-causing bacteria
infected.example: Several passengers were found to have the disease after they took the same flight as an infected person.

locate.definition: to find a certain place, or the position of someone or something
locate.example: These days, most taxi drivers use GPS to locate places they don't know how to drive to.

reward.definition: something that is given to someone in recognition of a good deed or difficult task he or she has accomplished
reward.example: Janice was given a reward of $2,000 for informing the police of the address of the man they were searching for.

ability.definition: the power to do a certain thing or a special thing that one can do
ability.example: Eagles have the ability to fly without landing for over three hours.

predict.definition: to guess that something will happen at a future time
predict.example: The weatherperson predicted that it would start raining around 6:00 p.m., and she was correct.

manage.definition: to put great effort into doing something and succeed
manage.example: Kyle managed to lose twenty pounds by exercising every day and eating less junk food.

create.definition: to cause something to come to be or to exist
create.example: The inventor of the telephone, Antonio Meucci, created a new way for humans to communicate.

expose.definition: to let someone experience something or to introduce something to someone
expose.example: By reading these articles, students will be exposed to different opinions about the topic.

perform.definition: to carry out an action, task, or duty
perform.example: After Mrs. Checknita fell ill, her family hired someone to help her perform daily tasks.

behavior.definition: the way a person or animal acts
behavior.example: Animal behavior can tell us a lot about what a creature is thinking about or wants.

alert.definition: a warning that there may be some sort of danger or some special problem
alert.example: Everybody was asked to leave the mall due to a bomb alert in one of the stores.

complete.example: The race is not complete until every runner from every team crosses the finish line.

assign.definition: to give a special task or role to a certain person
assign.example: Craig was assigned the task of giving the new students a tour of the school.

specific.example: There wasn't any specific reason why Jason didn't attend the performance with his friends. He just didn't feel like it.
